Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of HPC-B: A High Performance Computational Infrastructure for Biomedical Informatics Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: 12-29213
PI(s): Cao, Yu; Kizza, Joseph M; Li, Ming; Tanis, Craig;
Institution: University of Tennessee Chattanooga
Title: MRI: Acquisition of HPC-B: A High Performance Computational Infrastructure for Biomedical Informatics Research
Project Proposed:
This project, from an EPSCoR state and a non-PhD granting institution, acquiring a high performance computational infrastructure to be located at U. of Tennessee, Chattanooga (UTC), aims to support, as a shared facility, five research projects involving ten investigators and 18 students (9 UG, 6 MSc and 3PhD). The proposed projects explore three requirements for a viable, productive and usable health information technology. The project addresses the need to
- Retrieve relevant information from biomedical data, with accuracy and security;
- Analyze the data; and
- Disseminate and share the data.
Biomedical records hold enormous amounts of multimodal data. Thus, the research efforts described focus on actions needed to make this data available (complete, secure, and reliable).
The proposed research questions are organized into three main thrust areas: How to
- Discover clinically and biomedically important knowledge from complex biomedical multimedia data;
- Evaluate and improve the quality and safety of health care by analyzing the large amount of clinical data; and
- Facilitate the biomedical information collection, management, exchange, and analysis with large-scale network computing platforms and telemedicine systems.
The computational infrastructure is expected to serve as an essential shared research instrument, allowing researchers to analyze, design, develop, test, and deploy large-scale and distributed computer algorithms to address a variety of computationally-intensive and data-intensive biomedical informatics research challenges.
Broader Impacts:
Due to a large potential number of users, its convincing educational plan, outreach plan, as well as expected scientific discoveries in a very important area for every society: health care, this work exhibits potential for strong broader impacts. The programs to enrich broader impact aspects will not only be felt locally, but also internationally, and help to ensure that the country maintains leadership and innovation within the addressed research domains.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first major outcome of this project is the High Performance Computational Infrastructure serving multiple biomedical informatics and digital health research projects. The reasearch team, via close research discussions, interactions, and collaborations among team members, has delivered two High Performance Computing (HPC) systems as follows: (1) The first HPC system is a very powerful Dell cluster including the following components: (1.1) high end Dell servers with emphasizing on general computing; (1.2) large scale storage space with emphasizing on scalability and robust, and (1.3) other computing devices with emphasizing on supporting the first two components; (2) The second HPC system is a heterogonous cluster (a group of computers) system including following components: (2.1) a cluster with emphasizing on central processing unit (CPU) computing; (2.2) a cluster with emphasizing on Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) computing; and (2.3) a cluster with emphasizing on edge computing.

The second major outcome of this project is that the team has analyzed, designed, developed, tested, and deployed largescale and distributed computer algorithms to address a variety of computation intensive and data intensive biomedical informatics research challenges. Specifically, the team has investigated and developed new computer algorithms for knowledge discovery from complex biomedical multimedia data. The team designed and developed new computer-aided techniques for analyzing large amounts of clinical data in order to evaluate and improve the quality of health care. The team also researched into large-scale and network computing platforms and telemedicine systems to facilitate the biomedical information collection, management, exchange, and analysis.

The third major outcome of this project is the education and outreach activities conducted by the project team. This include the development of three new degree concentrations in Data Science: (1) Undergraduate concentration in Data Science; (2) MS In Data Science; (3) a Multidisciplinary PhD in Data Science with University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) and University of Tennessee, Health Sciences. The team also developed four courses with the support of this project: Big Data System Design, Multimedia Computing, Software Engineering I, and Software Engineering II. In addition, the research team, under the support this project, has successfully received six new external grant proposal in the areas of Biomedical Informatics, Digital Health, Big Data, and Deep Learning.


Last Modified: 10/05/2016
Modified by: Joseph M Kizza
